tn.text: "Son of a human being" or "Son of humanity." God calls Ezekiel this to emphasize that Ezekiel is only a human being. God is powerful and lives forever, but people are not. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:02:01|2:1]]. AT: "Mortal person" or "Human"

tn.ref: the word of Yahweh came to me
tn.text: "Yahweh gave me a message." See how you translated this phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:01:01|1:1]].

This is an idiom. This means to that Yahweh is casting judgement upon Jerusalem and is telling Ezekiel to look toward Jerusalem and speak his judgement against it. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:04:06|4:7]]. AT: "look in judgement upon Jerusalem" or "look towards Jerusalem with judgement"

tn.ref: I will draw my sword from its sheath and cut off both the righteous person and the wicked person from you
tn.text: This speaks of Yahweh causing these people to die as if he actually killed them with his own sword. AT: "I am opposed to you, and it will be as though I pull my sword from its sheath to kill both the righteous and the wicked people among you" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the righteous person and the wicked person
tn.text: "righteous people and wicked people." This refers to multiple people, not just one righteous person and one wicked person.
something that holds and covers a sword when no one is using it
This is a euphemism that means to kill. AT: "kill" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
Yahweh continues giving Ezekiel his message to the land of Israel.
This is a euphemism that means to kill. AT: "kill" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
This refers to righteous and wicked people. AT: "those who are righteous … those who are wicked" or "the righteous people … the wicked people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
"among you"

tn.ref: my sword will go out from its sheath against
tn.text: This speaks of Yahweh causing these people to die as if he actually killed them with his own sword. AT: "it will be as though I pull my sword from its sheath and strike" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "flesh" is a metonym for "people." AT: "all people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: from the south to the north
tn.text: This is a merism that refers to the area to the north, and to the south, and all places in between.  AT: "in every direction" or "everywhere" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])

tn.ref: that I, Yahweh, have drawn my sword from its sheath
tn.text: This speaks of Yahweh causing people to die as if he actually killed them with his own sword. AT: "it is as though I, Yahweh, have struck people with my sword" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: It will no longer hold back
tn.text: This speaks of Yahweh not holding back his sword from attacking people as if his sword were a person that was no longer holding itself back from attacking. AT: "and I will not put it back in its sheath again" (UDB) or "I will not hold back from attacking people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
Yahweh is speaking to Ezekiel.

"son of a human being" or "son of humanity" or "mortal person" or "human." God calls Ezekiel this to emphasize that Ezekiel is only a human being. God is powerful and lives forever, but people are not. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:02:01|2:1]].

Yahweh tells Ezekiel to groan as a sign to accompany his message. He tells him to groan deeply as if his abdomen was in great pain. "groan deeply as if your loins were in great pain"  or "groan deeply with great sorrow" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"With great grief" or "With great sorrow"
Here the Israelites are referred to by their "eyes" to emphasize what they see. AT: "before them" or "before the Israelite people" (See:   [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This speaks of the "news" as if it were a person that was soon coming to them. AT: "the news that they will soon hear" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: for every heart will faint away
tn.text: This speaks of people becoming afraid as if their hearts were fainting. Also, this speaks of being fearful as faints. AT: "for everyone will become fearful" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"will be weak"
This speaks of people becoming fearful in their spirits as if their spirits were about to faint. AT: "Everyone will be fearful in their inner being" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: every knee will flow like water
tn.text: "every knee will be as weak as water" (UDB). This is a euphemism for people being so afraid that they lose their bladder control and urinate on themselves. AT: "every leg will be wet with urine" or "everyone will lose control of their urine" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
"Yahweh spoke his word." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:01:01|1:1]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: It will be sharpened and polished
tn.text: AT: "It is sharp and polished." This phrase indicates that the sword is ready for someone to use it. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Someone made the sword smooth, shiny, and clean by rubbing it with a rough material.
Yahweh continues giving Ezekiel his message to the people of Jerusalem and of the land of Israel.

tn.ref: It will be sharpened ... It will be polished in order to
tn.text: These can be stated in active form. AT: "I will sharpen it … I will polish it so that it will" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: in order to be like lightning
tn.text: This means that the sword will be so shiny that light reflects off of it easily and brightly. AT: "so that it flashes like lightning" or "so that light reflects off of it as brightly as lightning" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: Should we rejoice in my son's scepter?
tn.text: This rhetorical emphasize that the people of Israel will not celebrate their king's power, because it cannot resist the "sword." AT: "The people of Judah will not celebrate about their king's scepter." or "we should not celebration the power of our king's scepter"  (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
The word "we" refers Ezekiel and the people of Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])

Here Yahweh refers to the king of Judah as his son. The king's scepter represents his rule as king. It is important to maintain the image of the king's scepter here, as it is reference in the next phrase. AT: "in the king's scepter" or "in the power represented by the king's scepter" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: The coming sword hates every such rod
tn.text: Here the "sword" is personified as coming to attack the people. This speaks of the king not being able to resist the "sword" as the "sword" hating the king's scepter. AT: "the sword will overpower his scepter like that of any other ruler" or "for the king will not be able to resist when the sword is brought against him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
This phrase is used to mock the king's scepter by calling it a "rod." AT: "such scepter" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_irony]])

tn.ref: the sword will be given to be polished
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "I will polish the sword" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: then to be grasped by the hand
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "then the right person will hold it in his hand" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: it is to be given into the hand of the one who kills
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "it is ready for the killer to use" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Yahweh continues giving Ezekiel his message to the people of Jerusalem and of the land of Israel.

tn.ref: They are thrown against the sword with my people
tn.text: "They are killed with the sword along with my people"

tn.ref: but what if the scepter does not last?
tn.text: AT: "and it will be very frightening if the sword destroys the scepter and the scepter is gone." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: A sword for the ones to be slaughtered
tn.text: AT: "A sword for slaughtering people." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The word "them" refers to the people of Jerusalem and of the land of Israel.
Yahweh continues giving Ezekiel his message to the people of Jerusalem and of the land of Israel.
Here "fallen" refers to the people killed in battle. AT: "to kill many people among them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The word "their" refers to the people of Jerusalem.

tn.text: It is as if Yahweh were talking to a sword. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_apostrophe]])
"wherever I have turned your blade."
Here "face" stands for the sword's edge.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
